lenders.name: Kristen, SoulChef
lenders.loan_because:
I want to see people fulfill their dreams of business ownership and helping them purchase the items they need means so much to me. 

I've always volunteered or donated goods, services, or money. But It's time to give back in a bigger way.  

Kiva gives me the tools to do that.

Whether my business succeeds in great leaps and bounds or one baby step at a time, I understand the demands & obstacles of attempting the huge feat of self-sufficiency by owning a business.

It's with this understanding & lots of compassion that I make loans with Kiva.

~Kristen
lenders.occupational_info:
As a former corporate climber with careers in finance, law and software development, I realized I was definitely making a living...I just wasn't living my truth. Today I am an Ayurvedic/Organic Personal Chef.  I specialize in Traditional cuisines from all over the world but my focus has been cooking for people suffering from dietary restrictions, obesity, & life threatening illnesses. 

I believe by using all my gifts, I can do my part in helping humanity; the reason I'm here in the first place.  I'm a student of life & love learning, sharing, cooking & of course, helping entrepreneurs get the money they need to succeed.

lenders.name: Suresh
lenders.loan_because: I am musician of old traditional music of Nepal,  i am street musician and selling a fetal in street ,  is because   i don't have enough capital to open a new retail shop in Nepal,
lenders.occupational_info:
My occupational back ground

The Gandharba are Nepal’s only traditional musician caste. According to myth, the original Gandharba descended from the heavens to spread local news, music and songs from community to community. In Hindu mythology the Gandharba were once the winged musicians of the Gods. Unfortunately, the Gandharbas belong to a caste that belongs to the "dalit" or “untouchables”- a title given to those born into a role that once left them within the socially and economically downtrodden groups of Nepal. Long before Television and the Radio, they travelled from place to place, playing their lively music and spreading news, making them messengers of the nation. Our ancestors would sing tales with themes ranging from battles and stories of long ago to local gossip, in exchange for a small amount of money or food. We played a significant role in spreading and preserving Nepali culture and folklore. During the unification of Nepal, King Prithivi Narayan Shah utilized the Gandharba people throughout the country to sing in favor of a united kingdom. Gandharbas further played a diplomatic and tactical role in the formation of Nepal as a united kingdom, by facilitating the transfer of information from one region to another, encouraging cooperation between the different districts that were finally uniting. Throughout Nepali History this has been the case, up until the present day, such as seen in the role played by the Gandharbas in the JANA ANDOLAN of 2006/2007.

The recent advances in modern media communication have displaced our traditional roles. Regular employment as a traditional Nepali folk musician is difficult to both find and secure, despite the fact that our music is a cultural treasure. We have little or no land and, due to poverty, many of us have not received an education beyond primary school. In an effort to find musical employment many Gandharbas have migrated to the main tourist areas of Nepal, hoping to sell an occasional Sarangi as a means of inconsistent income. We have our own culture, rituals, traditions and lifestyle, which we strive with the meager funds raised from sale of our musical instruments, or the occasional performances, to maintain in a modern, developing, ever more expensive world.

Relying so heavily on tourism as a source of income, most of the Gandharba living and working in the cities are left homeless and food-less during off-peak tourist seasons. Improved shelter, food, clothing, jobs, health and education are urgently required for this group of people to survive, as well as maintain their identity in this busy world. Still we wander form place to place, trying to make a living. Many of us have migrated from the village to the city with families in toe, looking for employment, better living conditions, and a better quality education for their children. The majority of Gandharbas are illiterate. Job discrimination is common - not a single senior level position in the government is held by a Gadharba. We have been involved in Dalit networks and in several programs involving but we are left out by the Dalit organizatons as well.


According to the census of 2001 AD, the Gandharba population counts approximately 5890. This account, however, is not believed to be accurate but rather an underestimate of the actual number, as it did not take into consideration that Gandharbas are also known by different surnames such as Ranjan, Baikar, Nepali, Gandhari

lenders.name: Jeanne
lenders.loan_because:
I want to see people succeed. 
I know what it is like to yearn for a better life and to get it. I am excited that I can help another person improve their quality of life.
lenders.occupational_info: I make jewelry, do skin care and work in weddings.

lenders.name: Thida
lenders.loan_because: I am not rich, but I can help those that are in desperate need, it is an amazing feeling.

lenders.name: Rob
lenders.loan_because: It's the "little things in life" that matter most.  Because I know this, I aim incessantly to make things "better" in "little ways" -- in my own life, and thereby hopefully in the lives of others.  I may be "poor" in some ways, but I never cease to count my blessings.  I have more than what I "need", and so wish to share the "excess" of what I have with those who have less yet strive and struggle mightily every single day  to "improve" their own lives and the future prospects of their children.  LIFE ain't "fair", and that's a fact.  My intention is to "offset" this fact as best I am able on an "individual basis" via this type of (Kiva) "micro-lending" . . . which I think is a potentially "world-changing" innovation!  I desire no thanks of any kind.  'Just "pass it on" to kith & kin -- and maybe the world will, eventually, become (a lot!) less "unfair".
lenders.occupational_info: Frankly, I am grossly "under"-employed.  And what I do is BORING!!  Yet, my fundamental task is to provide "service" to folks just like me. Therefore, this thought uppermost in my mind, I daily strive to provide the best possible "service" that I can.  My efforts in this regard are not noted by my "superiors", but they are ALWAYS appreciated by my  Customers!.  And doing well "by others" is exactly all that I wish to accomplish in this "job" that I presently hold.  It "pays-the-bills" -- and often that is MORE than most folks can (even) hope for!  Well, I'm doing "OK", and understand that MOST folks ain't.  So, my aim is to "share", one-to-one, what I've been blessed to "receive" with those who have "less".  I have "more", others have "less", I desire to share my "more" with those having "less".  It's just that simple.

lenders.name: David
lenders.loan_because: I live in a country that has given me opportunities than not everyone gets and the ability to touch people's lives with just a little bit of help is something I enjoy. I believe people in the world are willing to work to improve their own circumstances and giving people a handout does more harm than good. Kiva provides people with the help they need without stripping them of the dignity that comes from making your own success. I love this program.
lenders.occupational_info: I work on computer systems that allow hospitals to provide better care for patients. Hospitals have become very complex with a lot of information being generated about someone's health. The computer systems allow us to use that information to make sure that we catch problems that people could sometimes miss and prevent waste that increases cost. It's using computers to allow people to live happier and healthier lives.
